introduction: This video is about human-computer interaction and user interface design, hosted by Tony Tang, an associate professor at the University of Toronto. The session covers a mapping problem, focusing on how people map one series of things to another series of inputs. The video discusses the importance of understanding humans and computers to create successful communication and integrating computers into natural communication. The session concludes with a 15-minute break and the next session, 'Leave from wherever you are skills for an evolving profession' by Miriam Burgos, Marion Philips, Chris Stewart, and Harris Smith from the University of Southern California.

sections.title: Section 1: Introduction
content: Explanation of the session's topic and the presenter's background.
Overview of the main points covered in the session.
Presentation of the mapping problem and its significance in user experience design.

sections.title: Section 2: Understanding Humans and Computers
content: Discussion on how to make humans and computers understand each other and the importance of this understanding in user experience design.
Explanation of the development of machine intelligence and its impact on communication between humans and computers.
Presentation of the five categories of personality approachability, sentiment towards the user, professionalism, intelligence, and individuality in user interface design.

sections.title: Section 3: Mapping Problem Solutions
content: Presentation of two solutions to the mapping problem: placing icons next to the thing that should be plugged into them and using a ticket machine with clear instructions.
Discussion on the effectiveness of these solutions, especially for first-time users.
Comparison of these solutions to reading in North America and how they address the mapping problem.

sections.title: Section 4: Collaborative and Competitive Scenarios
content: Explanation of the importance of adapting user interface design for collaborative and competitive scenarios.

Presentation of proximix, a field of study concerned with how people organize their space and territory in terms of personality, approachability, sentiment, professionalism, intelligence, and individuality.
Discussion on how these categories differ for different ages and their relevance in user interface design.

sections.title: Section 5: Conclusion and Break
content: Summary of the main points covered in the session.
Introduction of the next session, 'Leave from wherever you are skills for an evolving profession'.
